image.altText: A small motorboat in front of a collapsed bridge with a large container ship underneath it

props.synopsis: Authorities continue to search for roadworkers who were on a bridge that was brought down by an out-of-control container ship, but say lives were saved by a mayday call from the vessel's crew.

title.children: 'We've gotta stop all traffic': Mayday call before US bridge collapse 'saved lives', but search goes on

image.altText: A screenshot of Muhammad Ali Waheed in a video call.

props.synopsis: Legitimately registered Australian companies are being used to shift scam victims' money overseas and it's proving a challenge for authorities trying to figure out who's responsible.

title.children: After Jo lost $500k through an Australian company, she thought it would be easy to track down. She was wrong

image.altText: two women fight for a football on a muddy oval.

props.synopsis: After one of the muddiest grand finals in NTFL history, how do grounds keepers turn mud back into grass in just four weeks?

title.children: After 'muddiest grand final ever', the race is on to get Darwin footy oval ready for NRL, AFL

image.altText: A retail store with pallets out front

props.synopsis: A lawyer for a homewares chain says the removal of a credit payment option is paternalistic and offensive to the vast majority of First Nations customers who have had no problems with the service.

title.children: Retailer claims ASIC ban is having 'disastrous' impact on First Nations customers

image.altText: Two hands holding a poster with a picture of a man on it with his mouth covered and the words "Free Assange"

props.synopsis: Julian Assange's supporters have described his ongoing incarceration as "punishment by process", but as his legal bids to avoid extradition to the United States drag on in Britain's legal system, a political solution could be the answer to ending the years-long saga.

title.children: Another day, another delay for Julian Assange's legal saga — this is why a political solution is in play

image.altText: Julian Assange looks to the camera as he is photographed from behind glass with graffiti etched into it. His grey hair is back.

props.synopsis: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange has been handed a legal lifeline by the High Court in London where he is trying to appeal his extradition to the United States.

title.children: Julian Assange handed extradition lifeline in court, US told not to seek death penalty

image.altText: a man smiling in front of a painting smiling

props.synopsis: Indigenous Australian art is celebrated globally. But who reaps the profits? Indigenous Australians are advised that this story contains the images and names of people who have died.

title.children: This late artist's egg-blue canvas sold for nearly $200,000 in New York. Back home, his family received nothing from the sale

image.altText: Melbourne fans wave flags at the Round 2 AFLW match between Collingwood and Melbourne at Victoria Park.

props.synopsis: Demons coach Simon Goodwin says he has no knowledge of allegations of off-the-books drug testing of players at the club, following claims made under parliamentary privilege by a federal MP.

title.children: 'News to me': Melbourne Football Club coach denies knowledge of alleged off-the-books drug tests

image.altText: Photo illustration of Peter Cullen Macarthur etched in the right-hand side of the screen and school books to the left

props.synopsis: Convicted sex offender Peter Cullen Macarthur was part of the peak body that investigated a Cranbrook teacher who was accused of sending sexually explicit emails to a former student.

title.children: Body that investigated Cranbrook teacher's explicit emails had convicted child sex offender on its board

image.altText: A close up photo of Chelsea looking serious.

props.synopsis: Chelsea Sirolli claims she was fired two days into a new job after her employers learned of her history in the sex industry.

title.children: Two days into a new job, Chelsea claims she was fired because of her past. She's challenging her employer

image.altText: A grassy hill overlooking an outback city.

props.synopsis: Buffel grass is valued as a form of cattle feed, but others say it poses unacceptable threats to the environment. In the coming months, a committee will rule on whether or not it should be declared a weed.

title.children: Committee to decide whether buffel grass should be declared a weed in the NT

image.altText: A stock market watcher stands in front of an ASX board.

props.synopsis: The Australian share market is trading sideways at open, while the Bureau of Statistics will release the monthly CPI data for February at 11.30am AEDT. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX flat ahead of monthly CPI data, Wall Street sinks

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Monthly inflation to tick temporarily higher
Australian companies used to hide scammers

image.altText: Andrew Giles in a blue suit and striped tie in house of representatives

props.synopsis: Immigration Minister Andrew Giles is set to gain new powers that will make it easier for the government to deport non-citizens.

title.children: Extraordinary powers to deport non-citizens may never be used, despite rush to legislate

image.altText: Older woman with green shirt and short white hair and glasses, sits in outdoor setting smiling with mouth closed.

props.synopsis: Experts argue the aged care system isn't adequately addressing elderly residents' mental health, but that government-funded sessions with a psychologist could help them feel happier and more at ease.

title.children: Half of all Australians in nursing homes experience depression. These experts say there's a simple solution to that

image.altText: A group of people walk towards a camera along a long hallway.

props.synopsis: The federal government's softened climate laws for cars have won the industry over, but it is yet to find the numbers to pass them in parliament — and the Greens warn not to count on their support.

title.children: Car makers have been won over on vehicle efficiency laws. The path through parliament may be harder

image.altText: A selfie of a young Asian woman near the water. She is looking directly into the camera.

props.synopsis: Women who are of working age make up the vast majority of almost five million Australians afflicted with migraine. Yet experts say many are needlessly suffering and it is ruining their careers and quality of life.

title.children: Chronic migraine attacks stole 17 years of Natalie's life. One injection gave her life back to her

image.altText: a large LNG ship in a harbour.

props.synopsis: Australia is one of the world's biggest gas exporters, yet is poised to start importing supplies from overseas. It's a situation that's drawn despair and surprise in equal measure.

title.children: Gas-rich Australia's looming need for LNG imports labelled 'bizarre' and nonsensical

image.altText: A graphic image showing the NDIS logo, a hand on a calculator, and stacks of folders.

props.synopsis: The Albanese government has introduced legislation to parliament paving the way for sweeping NDIS reforms. Here's what we know so far about the next steps.

title.children: As new NDIS legislation is unveiled, here's the latest on the future of the scheme

image.altText: A large building with burn marks and shattered windows sits against a grey sky with a russian flag flying in front of it

props.synopsis: Director of Russia's Federal Security Service Alexander Bortnikov made the comments in a television address.

title.children: 'Facilitated by Western special services': Russia's top spy chief blames West and Ukraine for Moscow attack

image.altText: A sale sign in a window

props.synopsis: This single biggest concern for millions of households, and the government, is inflation or the rising cost-of-living.

title.children: Higher interest rates 'wouldn't be catastrophic' as inflation expected to edge up

image.altText: A hand holding a smartphone showing an article about Princess Catherine's cancer diagnosis.

props.synopsis: You might hope we'd think for a moment about what it might be like to confront mortality as a baying mob rifles through your medical records, presses their faces up against your window, screaming, demanding you reveal yourself now.

title.children: Why are we so consumed by what 'should be' done as a doubtless traumatised 42-year-old mother grapples with her health?

image.altText: Luke Dorsett was killed on the Thunder River Rapids ride at Dreamworld.

props.synopsis: Luke Dorsett's mother has known for years that his final actions saved the life of his 12-year-old niece. Today his bravery has been nationally recognised, alongside several bystanders who rushed to help.

title.children: Dreamworld victim's heroic final act recognised with bravery award seven years after his death

image.altText: A film still of Kōji Yakusho, a 68-year-old Japanese man, smiling brightly, wearing blue coveralls that read "The Tokyo Toilet".

props.synopsis: In Perfect Days, German director Wim Wenders returns to Japan to follow the life of a Hirayama, as played by veteran Japanese actor Kōji Yakusho (Shall We Dance?).

title.children: Who knew the life of a Tokyo toilet cleaner would make for such a moving, Oscar-nominated film?

image.altText: Craig Goodwin of Australia fights for the ball.

props.synopsis: Australia have moved a step closer to qualifying for a sixth-straight FIFA World Cup after easing past Lebanon in Canberra, with winger Craig Goodwin the star.

title.children: Craig Goodwin steals the show as Socceroos thump Lebanon 5-0

image.altText: Staff serving customers at a fish market.

props.synopsis: There's a shortage of wild barramundi, king salmon and Spanish mackerel this Easter. But it's better news for lovers of prawns and lobster.

title.children: Barra or prawns? The choice will impact whether or not you'll have an Easter spread this year

image.altText: Young girl and boy with thumbs up, smiling at camera.

props.synopsis: After Rami and Yasmine's temporary visas were cancelled on their way from Gaza to Australia, they were forced to spend three days in limbo at Istanbul airport. Now, after a long and tiring journey, they've finally arrived and they're grateful. It's the family's first Ramadan away from home but they say they've been welcomed by local communities with open arms.

title.children: Nine-year-old Eleen used to have nightmares in Gaza. Now she's 'so excited' for a new life in Australia

image.altText: A man walks past a bed of flowers outside the entrance to Crown Casino.

props.synopsis: Despite years of wrongdoing, Melbourne's only casino will be allowed to keep its licence after two years of scrutiny by the Victorian gambling regulator.

title.children: The house wins again, as Crown keeps its casino licence

image.altText: Teenage girl sits up in bed and blows nose

props.synopsis: As the weather starts to cool, now is the time to start preparing for some very unwanted house guests. Here's the latest information about changes to vaccine guidelines, and new immunisations.

title.children: Want to avoid winter's unwanted house guests? Here's when to get your vaccinations

image.altText: A man in a white jumpsuit reclines in a chair within a glass cage as photographers gather outside.

props.synopsis: News that four of the suspects in the Moscow terror attacks are Tajik will likely result in further demonisation against people already facing poverty and discrimination, despite a glorious history.

title.children: This country has gone backwards fast over the past 100 years — and their anger is aimed at Russia

image.altText: A horse looks into a camera.

props.synopsis: The RSPCA is investigating after three emaciated thoroughbred horses were found on a property in southern Tasmania — animals which were once owned by Tasmania's former attorney-general Vanessa Goodwin.

title.children: Heartbreak, anger on social media over horses once owned by former Tasmanian attorney-general

image.altText: A satellite image from 2014 next to one from 2023 showing how much tree growth there has been in that time.

props.synopsis: Researchers find some of the nation's biggest polluters are meeting their emissions obligations using carbon credits that have not actually resulted in emissions reductions.

title.children: Biggest polluters meeting emissions rules using credits that did not reduce CO2, researchers find

image.altText: A close up of a sticker on car window, containing the word Uber.

props.synopsis: Uber has improved the experience of getting a ride so greatly that it might seem incomprehensible that it will pay Australia's fifth-largest class action to stop the case reaching court. What exactly did Uber do wrong?

title.children: Uber has settled a class action lawsuit for $270 million — what was it accused of?
